bestBHT.bht: The gospel is a gift of the grace of God, given to the apostle through the effectual working of His power. This gift bestowed upon the apostle is the apostleship to the Gentiles, which demonstrates the efficiency of God's transforming power. It is not by the apostle's own merit, but by the energy of God's power that he was qualified for this ministry. Through this verse, we can witness the manifestation of God's grace in calling and equipping individuals for the sacred task of spreading the gospel.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Gospel according to the gift of the grace of God.
Which (gift of grace) was given to me by the effectual working of His power.
The effectual working of His power.
Albert Barnes: According to the gift of the grace of God - It was not by my own seeking or merit; it was a free gift.

The sentiment is, that throughout it was a mere matter of grace that he was called into the ministry, and that so important an office was entrusted to him as that of bearing the gospel to the Gentiles.
It is by 'the energy of his power;'...nothing but the 'energy of God' could overcome it, and that his conversion was to be traced to that alone.
Marvin Vincent: The gift in which the grace of God consisted, the apostleship to the Gentiles.
The gift was bestowed in accordance with that efficiency which could transform Saul the persecutor into Paul the apostle to the Gentiles.
John Calvin: Having declared the gospel to be the instrument employed in communicating grace to the Gentiles, he now adds, that he was made a minister of the Gospel; and thus applies to himself the general statements which had been made.
Inquire not what I have deserved; for in the free exercise of kindness, the Lord made me an apostle of the Gentiles, not for any excellence of mine, but by his own grace.
To produce something great out of nothing, shews the effectual working of his power.
Philip Schaff: The word usually rendered ‘servant’ suggests the personal relation to the master; this one the obligation to service.
The ‘gift’ consisted of the ‘grace,’ and this was doubtless the apostolic office.
The giving was in accordance with God’s efficiency, not with Paul’s desert. Thus Saul became Paul; the persecuting Pharisee was transformed into the minister to the Gentiles.
Archibald T. Robertson: For this verse see Colossians 1:25; Ephesians 1:19; Ephesians 3:2.
John Gill: he is a true minister of the Gospel who is called of God to the work of the ministry, and is qualified by him with grace and gifts for it

for there may be all these, and yet a man not fit to be a minister of the Gospel; what qualifies men for that is the above gift, which God, of his sovereign good will and pleasure, gives to some of the sons of men

the power of God is seen in working grace in the hearts of men, thereby making them believers in Christ; and it is also displayed in the gifts of the Spirit bestowed on men, which is called a being endued with a power from on high; thereby making men, and not angels, and these oftentimes the meanest and weakest, ministers of Christ
John Wesley: According to the gift of the grace of God... the apostle-ship which he hath graciously given me."
By the effectual working of his power... In me and by me.
The apostle-ship which he hath qualified me for.

bhtAttempts.bht: The apostle speaks of the gospel as a gift of the grace of God, given to him by the effectual working of God's power. This gift is not based on the apostle's own seeking or merit, but is a free gift bestowed on him. It is by the energy of God's power that he was transformed from Saul the persecutor into Paul the apostle to the Gentiles. The apostleship itself is a manifestation of God's grace, a calling that was not deserved but given according to God's efficiency. Through this verse, we can see that God's power is at work, enabling and qualifying individuals for the ministry of the gospel.

The gospel is a gift of God's grace, bestowed on the apostle through the effectual working of God's power. It is by God's power that the apostle, formerly Saul the persecutor, was transformed into Paul, the apostle to the Gentiles. The apostleship itself is a manifestation of God's grace, given according to His efficiency. This verse highlights how God's power qualifies individuals for the ministry, enabling them to serve as ministers of the gospel.

The gospel is a gift of the grace of God, given to the apostle through the effectual working of His power. This gift bestowed upon the apostle is the apostleship to the Gentiles, which demonstrates the efficiency of God's transforming power. It is not by the apostle's own merit, but by the energy of God's power that he was qualified for this ministry. Through this verse, we can witness the manifestation of God's grace in calling and equipping individuals for the sacred task of spreading the gospel.

The gospel is a gift of the grace of God, given to the apostle through the effectual working of God's power. This gift of grace consisted of the apostleship to the Gentiles, bestowed in accordance with God's transforming efficiency. It was by the energy of God's power that Saul the persecutor was transformed into Paul the apostle, demonstrating the profound working of His power. Through this verse, we can recognize the divine qualification and calling that enables individuals to serve as ministers of the gospel.

The gospel is a gift of God's grace, given by the effectual working of His power, resulting in the apostleship to the Gentiles. This gift was bestowed according to God's efficiency, transforming Saul the persecutor into Paul the apostle. It is by the energy of God's power that such a conversion can occur. This verse highlights how God's power enables and qualifies individuals to serve as ministers of the gospel, a calling that is solely based on His grace.
